newsitem.title: USA: FCOJ futures settle weaker and at lows.
newsitem.headline: FCOJ futures settle weaker and at lows.

text.p: FCOJ futures closed weaker and towards the bottom of its recent range, signaling lower near-term prices, market analysts said.
The failure to sustain gains made earlier in the week sent benchmark July to a low of 81.55 cents, just over support pegged at 79.80 cents.

The spot month closed down 1.10 at 81.60 cents per lb, having traded from 82.90 to 81.55 cents. Second-position September ended 0.90 lower at 83.75, while the rest of the board finished 1.95 to 1.00 lower.
Analysts said the weak fundamental picture is keeping the market under significant pressure, even amid scattered talk of a pickup in demand.
But the Florida Citrus Processors Association reported FCOJ movement into trade channels for the week ended May 17 at 4,911,368 gallons compared with 4,659,784 gallons last week.
Despite the slight increase, the overall movement remains unimpressive.

"When one considers the build in stocks generated by this year's record harvest and combine this with an expected record 1997/98 Brazilian harvest, it is no wonder that the market continues to find difficulty sustaining rallies," Merrill Lynch analyst Judith Ganes, said in a weekly citrus comment.
An estimated 1,000 lots changed hands on the day, compared with Thursday's official 3,472 lots.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture will release its next Florida crop estimate on June 12. The last report put the crop at a record 224.2 million 90-lb boxes, and yields at 1.58 gallons per box.
